question: Question_01_(a)_ii
sols:
This is a quotient of functions and so let $\displaystyle f(x) = x$ and
$\displaystyle g(x) = \ln(\tfrac{1}{x})$. Then, by the quotient rule, we
have

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dx} \frac{x}{\ln(\tfrac{1}{x})} = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{g(x)^{2}}\end{align*}

Now, $\displaystyle f'(x) = 1$ and for $\displaystyle g'(x)$, we use the
chain rule to see that

$\displaystyle g'(x) = \frac{1}{\tfrac{1}{x}}(-x^{-2}) = -\frac{1}{x}$

Note, we could also have noticed that

$\displaystyle g(x) = \ln(\tfrac{1}{x}) = -\ln(x)$ and hence
$\displaystyle g'(x) = -\frac{1}{x}$.

Thus, combining all this information, we have

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dx} \frac{x}{\ln(\tfrac{1}{x})} &= \frac{(1)(\ln(\tfrac{1}{x})) - x\bigg(\frac{-1}{x}\bigg)}{(\ln(\tfrac{1}{x}))^{2}} \\ 
&= \frac{\ln(\tfrac{1}{x}) + 1}{(\ln(\tfrac{1}{x}))^{2}} \\
&= \frac{-\ln(x) + 1}{(-\ln(x))^{2}} \\
&= \frac{1-\ln(x)}{(\ln(x))^{2}}\end{align*}

and any of the last three answers would be accepted.
hints:
Try to run through an algorithm every time you compute a derivative. Do
you just know the derivative? If not what rules can you apply in this
situation? Notice that you're dividing two functions and that the bottom
function is a composition of two functions.

The quotient rule reads if $\displaystyle h(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}$ then

$\displaystyle h'(x) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{g(x)^{2}}$.

The chain rule reads if $\displaystyle h(x) = f(g(x))$ then

$\displaystyle h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)$.
